newsitem.title: USA: Chip stocks extend gains after upbeat report.
newsitem.headline: Chip stocks extend gains after upbeat report.

text.p: Semiconductor stocks, led by sector flagship Intel Corp, were mostly higher after the release of November figures that offered new evidence of a rebound in demand for computer chips in North America.
"I didn't think it was a startling figure, but it was a good one," J.P. Morgan chip analyst Terry Ragsdale said of the rise in November demand versus October.
Intel swelled 1-3/8 to 131-1/2. Other active stocks included Integrated Device Technology Inc, which gained 1/4 to 14-1/2, and SGS-Thomson Microelectronics NV, up 3/4 to 71-3/8 in U.S. trading.

Monday, the Semiconductor Industry Association reported the November book-to-bill ratio -- the industry's key monthly indicator -- rose to 1.15 in November from a revised figure of 1.11 in October, its highest level in more than a year.
"It was the fourth month in a row of sequential orders growth," Ragsdale said. "It just tends to confirm the view that we are at the beginning of a cyclical recovery," he said.

The 16-stock Philadelphia Semiconductor Index .SOXX opened broadly higher Tuesday, but fell back to show only slight gains by mid-morning. The index gained 2.04 points to 254.32, or roughly 0.81 percent on the day.
Half of the component stocks traded in positive territory in early trading, while two were unchanged and four stocks lower.

Laggards included chipset maker VLSI Technology Inc, which lost 1/2 to 27-7/8. Also, among semiconductor capital equipment suppliers, Applied Materials Inc was off 3/4 to 39, and Novellus Systems Inc was down 1/2 to 61-3/4.
The fourth index component to lose ground was programmable logic maker Lattice Semiconductor Corp, which dropped 7/8 to 45-1/8. Xilinx Inc shed 3/8 to 43-1/2.
